paragraph.leadIn: a licence for the supply, sale or transfer of, or the doing of any act likely to promote the supply, sale or transfer of, aviation fuel—

subparagraph.content: to the DPRK; or
to a destination or person for the purpose of delivery or transfer, directly or indirectly to the DPRK; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a licence for the carriage of aviation fuel that is, or forms part of, a carriage—

subparagraph.content: from a place outside the DPRK to a place in the DPRK; or
to a destination for the purpose of delivery or transfer, directly or indirectly to the DPRK.

subsection.content: The requirement is that the Committee has approved in advance on an exceptional case-by-case basis that the supply, sale, transfer or carriage of the aviation fuel to the DPRK is for verified essential humanitarian needs and is subject to specified arrangements for the effective monitoring of delivery and use.

section.name: s10K
section.heading: Licence for procurement of certain procurement-sanctioned items

subsection.leadIn: If on application the Chief Executive determines that the applicable requirements in subsection (2), (3) or (4) are met, the Chief Executive must grant, as appropriate—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: a licence for the procurement of, or the doing of any act likely to promote the procurement of, a procurement-sanctioned item referred to in the subsection concerned—

subparagraph.content: from the DPRK; or
from a person connected with the DPRK; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a licence for the use of a ship, aircraft or vehicle for or in connection with the procurement of a procurement-sanctioned item referred to in the subsection concerned—

subparagraph.content: from the DPRK; or
from a person connected with the DPRK.

subsection.leadIn: For coal, the applicable requirements are both of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the authority of a place outside the DPRK confirms, on the basis of credible information, that the coal has originated in that place and is transported through the DPRK solely for export from the Port of Rajin (Rason);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the procurement is unrelated to generating revenue for the DPRK’s nuclear or ballistic missile programmes or other activities prohibited by the Security Council Resolutions.

subsection.content: For a statue, the applicable requirement is that the Committee has approved the procurement in advance on a case-by-case basis.
For textiles (within the meaning of item 15 of Schedule 4), the applicable requirement is that the Committee has approved the procurement in advance on a case-by-case basis.

section.name: s10L
section.heading: Licence for certain activities in connection with DPRK banks

subsection.leadIn: If on application the Chief Executive determines that the requirement in subsection (2) is met, the Chief Executive must grant, as appropriate, a licence for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: establishing or maintaining a joint venture with a DPRK bank;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: acquiring or maintaining an ownership interest in a DPRK bank; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: establishing or maintaining a correspondent banking relationship with a DPRK bank.

subsection.content: The requirement is that the Committee has approved the activity concerned in advance on a case-by-case basis.

section.name: s10M
section.heading: Licence for opening or maintaining certain bank accounts

subsection.leadIn: If on application the Chief Executive determines that the requirements in subsection (2) are met, the Chief Executive must grant, as appropriate, a licence for opening a new bank account, or maintaining a bank account, for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a diplomatic mission or consular post of the DPRK; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an accredited diplomat or consular officer of the DPRK.

subsection.leadIn: The requirements are both of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the opening or maintaining of the bank account will not result in there being more than one bank account in the HKSAR for the diplomatic mission or consular post of the DPRK or the accredited diplomat or consular officer of the DPRK;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is no instruction from the instructing authority not to allow the bank account to be opened or maintained.

section.name: s10N
section.heading: Licence for provision of financial support for trade with persons connected with the DPRK

subsection.content: If on application the Chief Executive determines that the requirement in subsection (2) is met, the Chief Executive must grant a licence for the provision of financial support for trade with a person connected with the DPRK.
The requirement is that the Committee has approved the financial support in advance on a case-by-case basis.

section.name: s10O
section.heading: Licence for engaging in certain scientific or technical co-operation

subsection.content: If on application the Chief Executive determines that the requirement in subsection (2) is met, the Chief Executive must, subject to subsection (3), grant a licence for engaging in scientific or technical co-operation involving a person officially sponsored by the DPRK or a person representing the DPRK.

subsection.leadIn: The requirement is that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for scientific or technical co-operation in the field of nuclear science and technology, aerospace and aeronautical engineering and technology, or advanced manufacturing production techniques and methods—the Committee has determined on a case-by-case basis that the co-operation will not contribute to the DPRK’s proliferation of sensitive nuclear activities or ballistic missile-related programmes; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case—the co-operation will not contribute to the DPRK’s proliferation of sensitive nuclear activities or ballistic missile-related programmes.

subsection.content: If the Chief Executive determines that the requirement in subsection (2)(b) is met, before granting the licence, the Chief Executive must cause the Committee to be notified of the determination.

section.name: s11
section.heading: Licence for making available funds, etc. to certain persons or entities or dealing with funds, etc. of certain persons or entities

subsection.leadIn: If on application the Chief Executive determines that any of the requirements in subsection (2) is met, the Chief Executive must, subject to subsection (4), grant, as appropriate, a licence for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: making available funds or other financial assets or economic resources to, or for the benefit of, a relevant person or a relevant entity; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: dealing with funds or other financial assets or economic resources belonging to, or owned or controlled by, a relevant person or a relevant entity. (L.N. 5 of 2010; L.N. 115 of 2014)

subsection.leadIn: The requirements are as follows— (L.N. 54 of 2013)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the funds or other financial assets or economic resources are—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: necessary for basic expenses, including payment for foodstuffs, rents, mortgages, medicines, medical treatments, taxes, insurance premiums and public utility charges;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: exclusively for the payment of reasonable professional fees or reimbursement of incurred expenses associated with the provision of legal services under the law of the HKSAR; or (L.N. 122 of 2018)

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: fees or service charges, under the law of the HKSAR, for the routine holding or maintenance of funds or other financial assets or economic resources belonging to, or owned or controlled by, a relevant person or a relevant entity; (L.N. 115 of 2014)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the funds or other financial assets or economic resources are necessary for extraordinary expenses;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the funds or other financial assets or economic resources—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: are the subject of a judicial, administrative or arbitral lien or judgment that was entered before 14 October 2006 and is not for the benefit of a relevant person or a relevant entity or an individual or entity identified by the Committee or the Security Council; and (L.N. 140 of 2012)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: are to be used to satisfy the lien or judgment; (L.N. 5 of 2010; L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: both of the following—

subparagraph.content: the relevant person or relevant entity concerned falls within the definition of relevant person or relevant entity in section 1 because of the Foreign Trade Bank or the Korean National Insurance Company being named in the list published under section 31(1);

subparagraph.leadIn: the funds or other financial assets or economic resources are solely for—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: the operation of diplomatic or consular missions in the DPRK; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: humanitarian assistance activities that are undertaken by, or in co-ordination with, the United Nations; (L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: both of the following—

subparagraph.content: the relevant person or relevant entity concerned falls within the definition of relevant person or relevant entity in section 1 because of an entity referred to in section 31(2)(c) being named in the list published under section 31(1);

subparagraph.leadIn: the funds or other financial assets or economic resources—

subparagraph.name: A
subparagraph.content: are required to carry out activities of the DPRK’s missions to the United Nations and its specialized agencies and related organizations or other diplomatic and consular missions of the DPRK; or

subparagraph.name: B
subparagraph.content: are, as determined by the Committee in advance on a case-by-case basis, required for the delivery of humanitarian assistance, denuclearization or any other purpose consistent with the objectives of Resolution 2270. (L.N. 122 of 2018)

subsection.leadIn: If the Chief Executive determines that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the requirement in subsection (2)(a) is met, the Chief Executive—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: must cause the Committee to be notified of the intention to grant a licence under subsection (1); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: must grant the licence in the absence of a negative decision by the Committee within 5 working days of the notification;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the requirement in subsection (2)(b) is met, the Chief Executive—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: must cause the Committee to be notified of the determination; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: must not grant the licence unless the Committee approves the determination;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the requirement in subsection (2)(c) is met, before granting the licence, the Chief Executive must cause the Committee to be notified of the determination. (L.N. 5 of 2010)

section.name: s11A
section.heading: Licence for certain activities in connection with ships and aircraft

subsection.leadIn: If on application the Chief Executive determines that the requirement in subsection (2) is met, the Chief Executive must grant, as appropriate, a licence for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: leasing or chartering a ship or aircraft that is registered in the HKSAR to a relevant person, relevant entity or person connected with the DPRK;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: providing a ship or aircraft crewing service to a relevant person, relevant entity or person connected with the DPRK;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: registering a ship in the DPRK;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: obtaining an authorization for a ship to use the flag of the DPRK;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: owning, leasing, chartering or operating a ship registered in the DPRK;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: providing a ship classification, certification or associated service to a ship registered in the DPRK; or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: insuring a ship registered in the DPRK.

subsection.content: The requirement is that the Committee has approved the activity concerned in advance on a case-by-case basis.

subsection.leadIn: If on application the Chief Executive determines that the requirement in subsection (4) is met, the Chief Executive must grant, as appropriate, a licence for the provision of an insurance or reinsurance service to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a ship owned, controlled or operated by a person connected with the DPRK; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a ship that is involved in an activity prohibited by the Security Council Resolutions.

subsection.leadIn: The requirement is that the Committee determines on a case-by-case basis that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the ship is engaged in activities exclusively for livelihood purposes and will not be used by the DPRK’s individuals or entities to generate revenue; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the ship is engaged in activities exclusively for humanitarian purposes.

subsection.leadIn: If on application the Chief Executive determines that the requirement in subsection (6) is met, the Chief Executive must grant a licence for the provision of a ship classification service to a ship where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the ship—

subparagraph.content: was registered in the HKSAR and the registration was closed under section 64(6) of the Merchant Shipping (Registration) Ordinance (Cap. 415); or
was registered in a place outside the HKSAR and the registration was closed (however described) by the authority of that place; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the closure of registration was related to the ship’s involvement in an activity prohibited by the Security Council Resolutions.

subsection.content: The requirement is that the Committee has approved the provision of the ship classification service in advance on a case-by-case basis.

section.name: s11B
section.heading: Licence for joint ventures or co-operative entities with persons connected with the DPRK

subsection.leadIn: If on application the Chief Executive determines that the requirement in subsection (2) is met, the Chief Executive must grant, as appropriate, a licence for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: establishing, maintaining or operating a joint venture or co-operative entity with a person connected with the DPRK; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: investing in such a joint venture or co-operative entity.

subsection.content: The requirement is that the Committee has approved the joint venture or co-operative entity in advance on a case-by-case basis.

section.name: s12
section.heading: Provision of false information or documents for purpose of obtaining licences

subsection.leadIn: A person who, for the purpose of obtaining a licence, makes any statement or provides or produces any information or document that the person knows to be false in a material particular commits an offence and is liable— (L.N. 5 of 2010)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

subsection.leadIn: A person who, for the purpose of obtaining a licence, recklessly makes any statement or provides or produces any information or document that is false in a material particular commits an offence and is liable— (L.N. 5 of 2010)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Licence or permission granted by authorities of places outside HKSAR

subsection.content: If the circumstances described in subsection (2) apply, a provision of this Regulation that prohibits the doing of a thing by a person except under the authority of a licence does not have effect in relation to any such thing done in a place outside the HKSAR by the person. (L.N. 5 of 2010)

For the purposes of subsection (1), the circumstances are that the thing is done by the person under the authority of a licence or with permission granted, in accordance with any law in force in that place outside the HKSAR (being a law substantially corresponding to the relevant provision of this Regulation), by the authority competent in that behalf under that law. (L.N. 5 of 2010)

section.name: s14
section.heading: Investigation of suspected ships

subsection.leadIn: If any of the circumstances specified in subsection (1A) exists, an authorized officer may— (L.N. 115 of 2014; L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: either alone or accompanied and assisted by any person acting under the officer’s authority, board the ship concerned and search it and, for that purpose, use or authorize the use of reasonable force; and (L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: request the charterer, operator or master of the ship to provide any information relating to the ship or its cargo, or produce for inspection any of its cargo or any document relating to the ship or its cargo, that the officer may specify.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: The circumstances are as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the authorized officer has reason to suspect that the ship is one to which section 3 or 5 applies and it has been, is being or is about to be used in contravention of section 3(2) or (2AA) or 5(2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the authorized officer has reason to suspect that the ship is one to which section 3AA applies and it has been, is being or is about to be used as described in section 3AA(2)(a) and (b);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the ship carries cargo that has originated in the DPRK;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the ship carries cargo that is destined for the DPRK;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the ship carries cargo that has been brokered or facilitated by—

subparagraph.content: the Government or a national of the DPRK;
an individual acting on behalf of, or at the direction of, the Government or a national of the DPRK;
an entity acting on behalf of, or at the direction of, or owned or controlled by, the Government or a national of the DPRK;
a relevant person; or
a relevant entity;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the ship carries cargo and is using the flag of the DPRK. (L.N. 122 of 2018)

subsection.name: 1B
subsection.leadIn: If an authorized officer has reason to suspect—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that a ship to which section 3 or 5 applies is being or is about to be used in contravention of section 3(2) or (2AA) or 5(2); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that a ship to which section 3AA applies is being or is about to be used as described in section 3AA(2)(a) and (b),

subsection.continued: the officer may, for the purpose of stopping or preventing the ship from being so used or pursuing enquiries, either there and then or on consideration of any information provided, or cargo or document produced, in response to a request made under subsection (1)(b), do one or more of the acts specified in subsection (2). (L.N. 122 of 2018)

subsection.name: 1C
subsection.content: Also, if any of the circumstances specified in subsection (1A)(c), (d), (e) and (f) exists, an authorized officer may do one or more of the acts specified in subsection (2). (L.N. 122 of 2018)

subsection.leadIn: The acts are as follows— (L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: directing the charterer, operator or master of the ship to refrain, except with the consent of an authorized officer, from landing, at any port specified by the authorized officer, any part of the ship’s cargo that is so specified; (L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: requesting the charterer, operator or master of the ship to take any of the following steps— (L.N. 122 of 2018)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: to cause the ship and any of its cargo not to proceed with the voyage on which the ship is then engaged or about to be engaged until the charterer, operator or master is notified by an authorized officer that the ship and its cargo may so proceed;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the ship is in the HKSAR, to cause the ship and any of its cargo to remain in the HKSAR until the charterer, operator or master is notified by an authorized officer that the ship and its cargo may depart;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if the ship is in any other place, to take the ship and any of its cargo to a port specified by an authorized officer, and to cause the ship and its cargo to remain in that place until the charterer, operator or master is notified by an authorized officer that the ship and its cargo may depart;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: to take the ship and any of its cargo to another destination specified by an authorized officer in agreement with the charterer, operator or master.

subsection.leadIn: A power conferred by this section to request a person to provide any information or produce any cargo or document for inspection includes a power to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specify whether the information should be provided orally or in writing and in what form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the time by which, and the place in which, the information should be provided or the cargo or document should be produced for inspection.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Offences by charterer, operator or master of ship

subsection.content: A charterer, operator or master of a ship who disobeys any direction given under section 14(2)(a), or, without reasonable excuse, refuses or fails to comply with a request made under section 14(1)(b) or (2)(b) within the time specified by an authorized officer or, if no time is specified, within a reasonable time, commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

A charterer, operator or master of a ship who, in response to a request made under section 14(1)(b) or (2)(b), provides or produces to an authorized officer any information or document that the charterer, operator or master knows to be false in a material particular, or recklessly provides or produces to an authorized officer any information or document that is false in a material particular, commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s16
section.heading: Power of authorized officers to enter and detain ships

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 15, if an authorized officer has reason to suspect that a request that has been made under section 14(2)(b) may not be complied with, the officer may take any steps that appear to the officer to be necessary to secure compliance with that request including, in particular, any of the following steps—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter or authorize the entry on any land or the ship concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: detain or authorize the detention of that ship or any of its cargo;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: use or authorize the use of reasonable force.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), subsection (1) does not authorize the detention of a ship for more than 12 hours.

The Chief Secretary for Administration may, by order in writing, authorize the detention of a ship for further periods of not more than 12 hours each, and the order must state the time from which, and period for which, the order is effective.

section.name: s17
section.heading: Investigation of suspected aircraft

subsection.leadIn: If any of the circumstances specified in subsection (1A) exists, an authorized officer may— (L.N. 115 of 2014; L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: either alone or accompanied and assisted by any person acting under the officer’s authority, board the aircraft concerned and search it and, for that purpose, use or authorize the use of reasonable force; and (L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: request the charterer, operator or pilot in command of the aircraft to provide any information relating to the aircraft or its cargo, or produce for inspection any of its cargo or any document relating to the aircraft or its cargo, that the officer may specify.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: The circumstances are as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the authorized officer has reason to suspect that the aircraft is one to which section 3 or 5 applies and it has been, is being or is about to be used in contravention of section 3(2) or (2AA) or 5(2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the authorized officer has reason to suspect that the aircraft is one to which section 3AA applies and it has been, is being or is about to be used as described in section 3AA(2)(a) and (b);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the aircraft carries cargo that has originated in the DPRK;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the aircraft carries cargo that is destined for the DPRK;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the aircraft carries cargo that has been brokered or facilitated by—

subparagraph.content: the Government or a national of the DPRK;
an individual acting on behalf of, or at the direction of, the Government or a national of the DPRK;
an entity acting on behalf of, or at the direction of, or owned or controlled by, the Government or a national of the DPRK;
a relevant person; or
a relevant entity;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the aircraft is using the flag of the DPRK. (L.N. 122 of 2018)

subsection.content: If the aircraft referred to in subsection (1) is in the HKSAR, an authorized officer may, either there and then or on consideration of any information provided or cargo or document produced in response to a request made under subsection (1)(b), further request the charterer, operator or pilot in command of the aircraft to cause the aircraft and any of its cargo to remain in the HKSAR until the charterer, operator or pilot in command is notified by an authorized officer that the aircraft and its cargo may depart.

subsection.leadIn: A power conferred by this section to request a person to provide any information or produce any cargo or document for inspection includes a power to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specify whether the information should be provided orally or in writing and in what form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the time by which, and the place in which, the information should be provided or the cargo or document should be produced for inspection.

section.name: s18
section.heading: Offences by charterer, operator or pilot in command of aircraft

subsection.content: A charterer, operator or pilot in command of an aircraft who, without reasonable excuse, refuses or fails to comply with a request made under section 17(1)(b) or (2) within the time specified by an authorized officer or, if no time is specified, within a reasonable time, commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

A charterer, operator or pilot in command of an aircraft who, in response to a request made under section 17(1)(b) or (2), provides or produces to an authorized officer any information or document that the charterer, operator or pilot in command knows to be false in a material particular, or recklessly provides or produces to an authorized officer any information or document that is false in a material particular, commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Power of authorized officers to enter and detain aircraft

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 18, if an authorized officer has reason to suspect that a request that has been made under section 17(2) may not be complied with, the officer may take any steps that appear to the officer to be necessary to secure compliance with that request including, in particular, any of the following steps—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter or authorize the entry on any land or the aircraft concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: detain or authorize the detention of that aircraft or any of its cargo;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: use or authorize the use of reasonable force.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), subsection (1) does not authorize the detention of an aircraft for more than 6 hours.

The Chief Secretary for Administration may, by order in writing, authorize the detention of an aircraft for further periods of not more than 6 hours each, and the order must state the time from which, and period for which, the order is effective.

section.name: s20
section.heading: Investigation of suspected vehicles

subsection.leadIn: If any of the circumstances specified in subsection (1A) exists, an authorized officer may— (L.N. 115 of 2014; L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: either alone or accompanied and assisted by any person acting under the officer’s authority, board the vehicle concerned and search it and, for that purpose, use or authorize the use of reasonable force; (L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: request the operator or driver of the vehicle to provide any information relating to the vehicle or any article carried on it, or produce for inspection any article carried on it or any document relating to the vehicle or any article carried on it, that the officer may specify; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: further request, either there and then or on consideration of any information provided or article or document produced in response to a request made under paragraph (b), the operator or driver to take the vehicle and any article carried on it to a place specified by an authorized officer, and to cause the vehicle and the article to remain in that place until the operator or driver is notified by an authorized officer that the vehicle and the article may depart.

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.leadIn: The circumstances are as follows—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the authorized officer has reason to suspect that the vehicle is one in the HKSAR and it has been, is being or is about to be used in contravention of section 3(2) or (2AA) or 5(2);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the authorized officer has reason to suspect that the vehicle is one in the HKSAR and it has been, is being or is about to be used as described in section 3AA(2)(a) and (b);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the vehicle carries cargo that has originated in the DPRK;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the vehicle carries cargo that is destined for the DPRK;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: the vehicle carries cargo that has been brokered or facilitated by—

subparagraph.content: the Government or a national of the DPRK;
an individual acting on behalf of, or at the direction of, the Government or a national of the DPRK;
an entity acting on behalf of, or at the direction of, or owned or controlled by, the Government or a national of the DPRK;
a relevant person; or
a relevant entity. (L.N. 122 of 2018)

subsection.leadIn: A power conferred by this section to request a person to provide any information or produce any article or document for inspection includes a power to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: specify whether the information should be provided orally or in writing and in what form; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: specify the time by which, and the place in which, the information should be provided or the article or document should be produced for inspection.

section.name: s21
section.heading: Offences by operator or driver of vehicle

subsection.content: An operator or driver of a vehicle who, without reasonable excuse, refuses or fails to comply with a request made under section 20(1)(b) or (c) within the time specified by an authorized officer or, if no time is specified, within a reasonable time, commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

An operator or driver of a vehicle who, in response to a request made under section 20(1)(b) or (c), provides or produces to an authorized officer any information or document that the operator or driver knows to be false in a material particular, or recklessly provides or produces to an authorized officer any information or document that is false in a material particular, commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Power of authorized officers to enter and detain vehicles

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting section 21, if an authorized officer has reason to suspect that a request that has been made under section 20(1)(c) may not be complied with, the officer may take any steps that appear to the officer to be necessary to secure compliance with that request including, in particular, any of the following steps—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enter or authorize the entry on any land or enter or authorize the entry into the vehicle concerned;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: detain or authorize the detention of that vehicle or any article carried on it;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: use or authorize the use of reasonable force.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (3), subsection (1) does not authorize the detention of a vehicle for more than 12 hours.

The Commissioner may, by order in writing, authorize the detention of a vehicle for further periods of not more than 12 hours each, and the order must state the time from which, and period for which, the order is effective.

section.name: s22A
section.heading: Powers to stop and search etc.

subsection.leadIn: If an authorized officer has reasonable grounds to suspect that an offence under this Regulation has been, is being or is about to be committed, the officer may do one or more of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: stop and search a person arriving in or about to leave the HKSAR and examine anything in the person’s possession;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: examine at a point of entry to or exit from the HKSAR—

subparagraph.content: any cargo (other than any baggage), together with any manifest and supporting documents;
any unaccompanied baggage; or
any unaccompanied personal belongings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: examine any cargo (other than any baggage), together with any manifest and supporting documents—

subparagraph.content: at a place where the cargo is stored before it is exported from the HKSAR; or
at a place where the cargo is stored after it has been imported into the HKSAR and before, or at the time of, its collection by the consignee.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may seize and detain anything—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: found as a result of the exercise of a power under subsection (1); and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that the officer reasonably suspects to be connected with a contravention of this Regulation.

subsection.content: A person may only be searched under this section by a person who is of the same sex.
An authorized officer may use any force reasonably necessary for exercising a power under subsection (1) or (2).

section.name: s22B
section.heading: Arrest and detention

subsection.content: An authorized officer may without warrant arrest or detain for further inquiries a person whom the officer reasonably suspects of having contravened this Regulation.
An authorized officer who arrests a person under subsection (1) must take the person to a police station to be dealt with in accordance with the Police Force Ordinance (Cap. 232).

However, if further inquiries are necessary, an authorized officer (other than a police officer) may take the person to an office of the Customs and Excise Department for further inquiries before taking the person to a police station in accordance with subsection (2).
A person must not be detained for more than 48 hours from the time the person is arrested without being charged and brought before a magistrate.
An authorized officer who arrests a person may require the person to give the person’s name and to produce evidence of identity to the officer.
If a person forcibly resists or attempts to evade arrest under this section, an authorized officer may use any force reasonably necessary to effect the arrest.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Production of proof of identity
section.content: Before or on exercising a power conferred by section 14, 16, 17, 19, 20, 22, 22A or 22B, an authorized officer must, if requested by any person so to do, produce proof of the officer’s identity to the person for inspection.

section.name: s23A
section.heading: Interpretation of Part 6
section.def: material (材料) includes any book, document or other record in any form, and any article or substance;
possession (管有) includes control;

def.name: Premises
def.leadIn: premises (處所) includes any place and, in particular, includes—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any ship, aircraft, vehicle or offshore structure; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any tent or movable structure;

section.def: seized property (被檢取財產) means anything seized under section 22A(2) or 24(3).

section.name: s23B
section.heading: Order to make material available

subsection.content: The Secretary for Justice or an authorized officer may, for the purpose of an investigation into an offence under this Regulation, make an ex parte application, by information on oath, to a judge for an order under subsection (2) in relation to particular material or to material of a particular description.

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (3), the judge may on the application make an order—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: that the person who appears to the judge to be in possession of the material must, within the period specified in the order—

subparagraph.content: produce the material to an authorized officer for the officer to take away; or
give an authorized officer access to the material;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: that the person who appears to the judge likely to come into possession of the material must, within the period specified in the order—

subparagraph.content: produce the material to an authorized officer for the officer to take away; or
give an authorized officer access to the material; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in terms both of paragraphs (a) and (b).

subsection.leadIn: The judge may make the order only if the judge is satisfied—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that the offence has been committed;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that there are reasonable grounds for believing that the material is likely to be relevant to the investigation for the purpose of which the application is made;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: that there are reasonable grounds for believing that it is in the public interest that the material should be produced or that access to it should be given, having regard to—

subparagraph.content: the benefit likely to accrue to the investigation if the material is obtained; and
the circumstances under which the person in possession of the material holds, or will hold, it; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: for an application relating to material of a particular description—that an application in relation to particular material is not reasonably practicable.

subsection.leadIn: The period to be specified in the order must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for subsection (2)(a)—a period of 7 days after the date on which the order is served on the person concerned; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: for subsection (2)(b)—a period of 7 days after the later of the following dates—

subparagraph.content: the date on which the order is served on the person concerned;
the date on which the person concerned comes into possession of the material,

subsection.continued: unless it appears to the judge that a longer or shorter period would be appropriate in the particular circumstances of the application.

subsection.content: If the application relates to material outside the HKSAR, it may be made only by the Secretary for Justice.
The application must be heard in camera.
As soon as practicable after an order is made under subsection (2), the Secretary for Justice or authorized officer must serve the order personally on the person who is subject to the order.

section.name: s23C
section.heading: Supplementary provisions to section 23B

subsection.leadIn: An order under section 23B(2), in so far as it is in terms of paragraph (b) of that section, ceases to have effect on the expiry of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 3 months after the date on which the order is made; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any lesser period specified in the order.

subsection.leadIn: However, subsection (1) does not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: affect any obligation incurred under the order before it ceases to have effect; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prevent, whether before or after the order (first order) ceases to have effect, the making of any further order under section 23B(2) in respect of the person who is subject to the first order.

subsection.content: If a judge makes an order under section 23B(2)(a)(ii) or (b)(ii) in relation to material on any premises, a judge may, on the same application or a subsequent application by the Secretary for Justice or an authorized officer, order any person who appears to the judge to be entitled to grant entry to the premises to allow an authorized officer to enter the premises to obtain access to the material.

subsection.leadIn: If the material to which an application under section 23B(1) relates consists of information recorded otherwise than in a legible form—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an order under section 23B(2)(a)(i) or (b)(i) has effect as an order to produce the material in a form in which it can be taken away; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an order under section 23B(2)(a)(ii) or (b)(ii) has effect as an order to give access to the material in a form in which it is visible and legible.

subsection.leadIn: If an order under section 23B(2)(a)(i) or (b)(i) relates to information recorded otherwise than in a legible form, an authorized officer may, by notice in writing served on the person concerned—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: require the person to produce the material in a form in which it is visible and legible and can be taken away; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: release the person from any obligation under the order to produce the material in the form in which it was recorded.

subsection.content: An authorized officer may photograph or make copies of any material produced under this section or section 23B.

Subject to section 23F, a person is not excused from producing any material in relation to which an order under section 23B(2) is made on the ground that to do so would breach an obligation as to secrecy or another restriction on the disclosure of information imposed by statute or otherwise.
An application under subsection (3) must be heard in camera.

section.name: s23D
section.heading: Revocation or variation of order under section 23B or 23C

subsection.content: A person who is subject to an order under section 23B(2) or 23C(3) may apply for the revocation or variation of the order.
The application must be made to a judge by a summons supported by an affidavit.
The summons and affidavit in support must state the grounds on which the applicant seeks the revocation or variation of the order and the relevant facts.
The summons and a copy of the affidavit in support must be served on the Secretary for Justice not less than 3 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the application.
At the hearing of the application, the judge may revoke or vary the order as the judge considers appropriate.

section.name: s23E
section.heading: Procedures for application under section 23B, 23C or 23D

subsection.content: This section applies to an application made under section 23B, 23C or 23D.
At the hearing of the application, a judge may receive evidence.
All documents and information relating to the application must be treated as confidential.

All documents, and anything containing any information, relating to the application must, immediately after the application is determined, be placed in a packet and sealed by order of the judge hearing the application.

subsection.leadIn: The packet—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be kept in the custody of the court in a place to which the public has no access or in another place authorized by the judge;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must not be opened, and its contents must not be removed, except by order of a judge; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: must not be destroyed except by order of a judge.

section.name: s23F
section.heading: Privileges

subsection.leadIn: An order under section 23B(2) does not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: confer any right to production of, or access to, any item subject to legal professional privilege; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: restrict the privilege against self-incrimination.

subsection.leadIn: If, in the course of the exercise of powers conferred by an order under section 23B(2), a claim of legal professional privilege is made in respect of any material, the person making the claim must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the presence of an authorized officer, secure the material in a sealed container;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: deposit the sealed container with a judge as soon as practicable or handle the sealed container in another way as directed by a judge;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: within 3 days of so depositing or handling the sealed container, apply to a judge by a summons supported by an affidavit for a declaration that the material is an item subject to legal professional privilege; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: not less than 3 clear days before the date fixed for the hearing of the application, serve the summons and a copy of the affidavit in support on the Secretary for Justice.

section.name: s23G
section.heading: Offence for failure to comply with order under section 23B
section.content: A person who, without reasonable excuse, fails to comply with an order under section 23B(2) commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s23H
section.heading: Investigation not to be prejudiced

subsection.content: This section applies if an order under section 23B(2) has been made, or has been applied for and has not been refused.

subsection.leadIn: A person who knows or suspects that an investigation in relation to which the order has been made or applied for is taking place must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without lawful authority or reasonable excuse, make any disclosure intending to prejudice the investigation; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: falsify, conceal, destroy or otherwise dispose of, or cause or permit the falsification, concealment, destruction or disposal of, any material—

subparagraph.content: knowing or suspecting that the material is likely to be relevant to the investigation; and
intending to conceal the facts disclosed by the material from persons carrying out the investigation.

subsection.content: If a person has been arrested in connection with an investigation referred to in subsection (2), that subsection does not apply as regards any disclosure in respect of the investigation made after the arrest.

subsection.leadIn: A person who contravenes subsection (2) commits an offence and is liable—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Power of magistrate or judge to grant warrant

subsection.leadIn: A magistrate or judge may grant a warrant if satisfied by information on oath given by an authorized officer that there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that— (L.N. 5 of 2010)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an offence under this Regulation has been committed or is being committed; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: there is on any premises specified in the information evidence in relation to the commission of the offence.

subsection.content: A warrant granted under subsection (1) may authorize any authorized officer, together with any other person named in the warrant, to enter the premises specified in the information at any time within one month from the date of the warrant, and to search the premises.

subsection.leadIn: A person authorized by a warrant to search any premises may exercise any or all of the following powers— (L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: search any person who is found on, or whom the authorized person has reasonable grounds to believe to have recently left or to be about to enter, the premises; (L.N. 5 of 2010)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: seize and detain anything found on the premises or on any person referred to in paragraph (a) that the authorized person has reasonable grounds to believe to be evidence in relation to the commission of an offence under this Regulation; (L.N. 5 of 2010)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: take in relation to anything seized under paragraph (b) any other steps that may appear necessary for preserving it and preventing interference with it. (L.N. 5 of 2010)

subsection.content: A person may only be searched under this section by a person who is of the same sex.
If a person is empowered under this section to enter any premises, the person may use any force that is reasonably necessary for that purpose. (L.N. 5 of 2010)

division.name: D4
division.heading: Forfeiture and Detention of Seized Property

section.name: s24A
section.heading: Seized property liable to forfeiture

subsection.content: If an authorized officer intends to apply to a magistrate or judge under section 24B for an order for forfeiture of any seized property, the officer must, within 30 days from the date of the seizure, serve notice of that intention on every person who was, to the knowledge of the officer at the time of, or immediately after, the seizure, an owner of the seized property.

subsection.leadIn: A notice under subsection (1) is to be regarded as having been duly served on a person if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: it is delivered personally to the person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it is sent by registered post addressed to the person at any place of residence or business of the person known to the authorized officer; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where the notice cannot be served in accordance with paragraph (a) or (b), the notice is exhibited at the offices of the Customs and Excise Department, in a place to which the public have access, for a period of not less than 7 days commencing within 30 days from the date of the seizure of the seized property.

subsection.content: An owner, or the authorized agent of an owner, of the seized property referred to in a notice served under subsection (1), or a person who was in possession of the seized property at the time of seizure, or a person who has a legal or equitable interest in the seized property, may object to the proposed forfeiture by serving a notice in writing on the Commissioner.

subsection.leadIn: A notice of objection under subsection (3)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: must be served on the Commissioner by a person referred to in subsection (3) (claimant) within 30 days from—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: if the notice under subsection (1) is delivered personally to the person named in the notice, the date of delivery;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if the notice under subsection (1) is sent by registered post, 2 days after the date of posting; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: if the notice under subsection (1) is exhibited as described in subsection (2)(c), the first day it is so exhibited;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must state the claimant’s full name and address for service in Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: if the claimant does not have a permanent address in Hong Kong, must state the name and address of a solicitor who is qualified to practise under the Legal Practitioners Ordinance (Cap. 159) and is authorized to accept service on behalf of the claimant in relation to any forfeiture proceedings.

subsection.leadIn: An authorized officer may apply to a magistrate or judge for an order for forfeiture of any seized property in respect of which a notice has been served under subsection (1)— (L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.content: if a notice of objection is served in accordance with subsections (3) and (4), after the receipt of the notice.

section.name: s24B
section.heading: Power of magistrate or judge to make order for forfeiture and disposal

subsection.content: If an application is made to a magistrate or judge for an order for forfeiture of any seized property, the magistrate or judge may, if satisfied that the seized property is a prohibited item or a document relating to the provision, manufacture, maintenance or use of a prohibited item, make such order as the magistrate or judge considers appropriate for the forfeiture of the seized property and its subsequent destruction or disposal. (L.N. 122 of 2018)
An order under subsection (1) may be made in respect of any seized property whether or not any person has been convicted of any offence in connection with the seized property. (L.N. 122 of 2018)

Before making an order for forfeiture of any seized property, a magistrate or judge must issue a summons to any person who serves a notice of objection in accordance with section 24A(3) and (4) to appear on a day specified in the summons to show cause why the seized property should not be forfeited. (L.N. 122 of 2018)

If any summons issued under subsection (3) has not for any reason been served and the magistrate or judge is satisfied that all reasonable efforts have been made to serve the summons on the person named in the summons, the magistrate or judge may make an order for forfeiture under this section despite the fact that the summons has not been served on that person.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Detention of seized property

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2) and any order made under section 24B, any seized property may not be detained for more than 3 months.
If the seized property is relevant to an offence under this Regulation, and proceedings for the offence have begun, it may be detained until the completion of those proceedings.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Disclosure of information or documents

subsection.leadIn: Any information or document provided, produced or seized under this Regulation may be disclosed only if— (L.N. 5 of 2010)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person who provided or produced the information or document or from whom the document was seized has given consent to the disclosure; (L.N. 5 of 2010)

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.leadIn: the information or document is disclosed on the authority of the Chief Executive, subject to the information or document being transmitted through and with the approval of the instructing authority, to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any organ of the United Nations;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any person in the service of the United Nations; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the Government of any place outside the People’s Republic of China,

paragraph.continued: for the purpose of assisting the United Nations or that Government in securing compliance with, or detecting evasion of, measures in relation to the DPRK decided on by the Security Council; or (L.N. 5 of 2010)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the information or document is disclosed with a view to the institution of, or otherwise for the purposes of, any proceedings for an offence under this Regulation.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(a)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person may not give consent to the disclosure if the person has obtained the information or possessed the document only in the person’s capacity as servant or agent of another person; and (L.N. 5 of 2010)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person may give consent to the disclosure if the person is entitled to the information or to the possession of the document in the person’s own right. (L.N. 5 of 2010)

section.name: s27
section.heading: Liability of persons other than principal offenders

subsection.content: If the person convicted of an offence under this Regulation is a body corporate and it is proved that the offence was committed with the consent or connivance of, or was attributable to any neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate, the director, manager, secretary or other similar officer is guilty of the like offence.

If the person convicted of an offence under this Regulation is a firm and it is proved that the offence was committed with the consent or connivance of, or was attributable to any neglect on the part of, any partner in the firm or any person concerned in the management of the firm, the partner or the person concerned in the management of the firm is guilty of the like offence.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Offences in relation to obstruction of authorized persons, etc.
section.content: A person who obstructs another person (including a person acting under the authority of an authorized officer) in the exercise of the powers of that other person under this Regulation commits an offence and is liable on conviction to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s29
section.heading: Offences in relation to evasion of this Regulation
section.leadIn: A person who destroys, mutilates, defaces, secretes or removes anything with intent to evade any of the provisions of this Regulation commits an offence and is liable— (L.N. 5 of 2010; L.N. 122 of 2018)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: on conviction on indictment—to a fine and to imprisonment for 2 years; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on summary conviction—to a fine at level 6 and to imprisonment for 6 months.

section.name: s30
section.heading: Consent and time limit for proceedings

subsection.content: Proceedings for an offence under this Regulation may only be instituted by or with the consent of the Secretary for Justice.

Summary proceedings for an offence under this Regulation that is alleged to have been committed outside the HKSAR may be commenced at any time not later than 12 months from the date on which the person charged first enters the HKSAR after the alleged commission of the offence. (L.N. 5 of 2010)

section.name: s31
section.heading: Publication of list of individuals and entities by Secretary

subsection.content: The Secretary may publish on the website of the Commerce and Economic Development Bureau a list of individuals and entities for the purposes of the definitions of relevant person and relevant entity in section 1.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may include in the list the name of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an individual or entity designated by the Committee or the Security Council for the purposes of paragraph 8(d) of Resolution 1718;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an individual or entity to whom measures referred to in paragraph 8(d) of Resolution 1718 apply under a decision of the Committee or the Security Council; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an entity of the Government of the DPRK or of the Worker’s Party of Korea determined by the instructing authority as an entity associated with the DPRK’s nuclear or ballistic missile programmes or other activities prohibited by Resolution 1718, Resolution 1874, Resolution 2087, Resolution 2094 or Resolution 2270.

subsection.content: The list may also contain other information that the Secretary considers appropriate.
The Secretary may remove the name of an individual or entity from the list if the individual or entity no longer meets the description under subsection (2).

If a list is published under subsection (1), the Secretary is to make a copy of the list available for inspection by the public free of charge at the office of the Secretary during normal office hours.

subsection.leadIn: In any legal proceedings, a document purporting to be a copy printed from the website referred to in subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is admissible in evidence on production without further proof; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: unless the contrary is proved, is evidence of the information contained in the list of individuals and entities referred to in that subsection.

section.name: s31A
section.heading: Publication of list of ships by Secretary

subsection.content: The Secretary may publish on the website of the Commerce and Economic Development Bureau a list of ships for the purposes of the definition of relevant ship in section 10A(4).

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary may include in the list the name of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a ship designated by the Committee or the Security Council for the purposes of paragraph 8(d) of Resolution 1718, paragraph 12 of Resolution 2270 or paragraph 12 of Resolution 2321; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a ship to which measures referred to in paragraph 8(d) of Resolution 1718, paragraph 12 of Resolution 2270 or paragraph 12 of Resolution 2321 apply under a decision of the Committee or the Security Council.

subsection.content: The list may also contain other information that the Secretary considers appropriate.
The Secretary may remove the name of a ship from the list if the ship no longer meets the description under subsection (2).

If a list is published under subsection (1), the Secretary is to make a copy of the list available for inspection by the public free of charge at the office of the Secretary during normal office hours.

subsection.leadIn: In any legal proceedings, a document purporting to be a copy printed from the website referred to in subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is admissible in evidence on production without further proof; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: unless the contrary is proved, is evidence of the information contained in the list of ships referred to in that subsection.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Exercise of powers of Chief Executive

subsection.content: The Chief Executive may delegate any of the Chief Executive’s powers or functions under this Regulation to any person or class or description of person.

A delegation or authorization under subsection (1) or (2) may be subject to any restrictions or conditions that the Chief Executive considers appropriate. (L.N. 122 of 2018)

subsection.content: The Secretary may delegate any of the Secretary’s powers or functions under this Regulation to any person or class or description of person.
